jparsec.util

Class DataBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.util.DataBase

  • public class DataBase
extends java.lang.Object
    A basic abstraction of a database to hold objects in memory or in disk.

    This class holds objects in memory or serialized in files. Data is identified by a String that holds the data identifier and the process id. This String is used as the name for the serialized file for slow performance but unlimited memory mode, very useful for Android. The use of a process id allows also to access data in a thread-safe way. As the identifier of the thread the thread's name is used, as returned by ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID().

    In JPARSEC all information is kept in memory for better performance.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)

    • Method Detail

      • addData

        public static java.lang.String addData(java.lang.String id,
                       java.lang.Object o,
                       boolean forceMemory)
        Adds data to the database. Process id is determined using ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID().
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        o - The set of objects.
        forceMemory - True to force the use of the memory instead of disk. Useful to store little objects used frequently, that would slow down the execution if the are continuously accessed through disk.
        Returns:
        The identifier of the thread writing this data.

      • addData

        public static java.lang.String addData(java.lang.String id,
                       java.lang.String pid,
                       java.lang.Object o,
                       boolean forceMemory)
        Adds data to database. In case the data already exists, it is replaced with the new data.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        pid - The process id, should be identical to ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID(). You can set it here since the mentioned method uses reflection and it is slow. pid can also be null for static objects (for all process).
        o - The set of objects.
        forceMemory - True to force the use of the memory instead of disk. Useful to store little objects used frequently, that would slow down the execution if the are continuously accessed through disk.
        Returns:
        The identifier of the thread writing this data.

      • addData

        public static java.lang.String addData(java.lang.String id,
                       java.lang.String pid,
                       java.lang.Object o,
                       boolean forceMemory,
                       int lifeTimeSeconds)
        Adds data to database. In case the data already exists, it is replaced with the new data.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        pid - The process id, should be identical to ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID(). You can set it here since the mentioned method uses reflection and it is slow. pid can also be null for static objects (for all process).
        o - The set of objects.
        forceMemory - True to force the use of the memory instead of disk. Useful to store little objects used frequently, that would slow down the execution if the are continuously accessed through disk.
        lifeTimeSeconds - Life time of the data in seconds. In case data is requested after this period, it will be deleted and null would be returned. Set to 0 or negative for infinity life time.
        Returns:
        The identifier of the thread writing this data.

      • getData

        public static java.lang.Object getData(java.lang.String id,
                       boolean forceMemory)
        Returns data from the database. Process id is determined using ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID().
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        forceMemory - True to force the use of the memory instead of disk. Useful to store little objects used frequently, that would slow down the execution if the are continuously accessed through disk.
        Returns:
        The set of objects, or null if none can be found.

      • getDataForAnyThread

        public static java.lang.Object getDataForAnyThread(java.lang.String id,
                                   boolean forceMemory)
        Returns data from the database. A search is performed over all existent process ids until data is found.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        forceMemory - True to force the use of the memory instead of disk. Useful to store little objects used frequently, that would slow down the execution if the are continuously accessed through disk.
        Returns:
        The set of objects, or null if none can be found.

      • dataExists

        public static boolean dataExists(java.lang.String id,
                 boolean anyThread)
        Returns if a given identifier holds data in the database.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier for the data.
        anyThread - True to scan all thread, false for the one calling this method.
        Returns:
        True or false.

      • dataExists

        public static boolean dataExists(java.lang.String id,
                 java.lang.String threadName,
                 boolean inMemory)
        Returns if a given identifier holds data in the database.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier for the data.
        threadName - Thread name.
        inMemory - True to check in memory, false to check on disk cache.
        Returns:
        True or false.

      • getData

        public static java.lang.Object getData(java.lang.String id,
                       java.lang.String pid,
                       boolean forceMemory)
        Returns data from the database.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        pid - The process id, should be identical to ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID(). You can set it here since the mentioned method uses reflection and it is slow. pid can also be null for static objects (for all process).
        forceMemory - True to force the use of the memory instead of disk. Useful to store little objects used frequently, that would slow down the execution if the are continuously accessed through disk. THIS FLAG IS DISABLED, CURRENTLY EVERYTHING IS FORCED TO BE ON MEMORY.
        Returns:
        The set of objects, or null if none can be found.

      • getData

        public static java.lang.Object getData(int index)
        Returns the data for a given index in the database, without any kind of check.
        Parameters:
        index - The index.
        Returns:
        The data.

      • getIndex

        public static int getIndex(java.lang.String id,
           java.lang.String pid)
        Returns the index of a specific item in the database.
        Parameters:
        id - The identifier of the data.
        pid - The process id, should be identical to ApplicationLauncher.getProcessID(). You can set it here since the mentioned method uses reflection and it is slow. pid can also be null for static objects (for all process).
        Returns:
        The index for the item in the database, or -1 if it is not found.

        Sets the cache directory.
        Parameters:
